summary:
Experienced Bioanalytical Research Associate with a strong background in Biology, specializing in ELISA, ECLIA, cell culture, cytotoxicity assays, and PK studies. Skilled in scientific illustration and poster design. MSc in Advanced Immunology with a history of impactful research projects. Proficient in laboratory techniques, project management, and interdisciplinary collaboration.

Key Highlights: 
- Current Bioanalytical Research Associate at ADC Therapeutics. 
- Accomplished scientific illustrator and poster designer. - Diverse research experience in cell biology, immunology, and neurodegenerative diseases. 
- Strong foundation in laboratory techniques, including ELISA and cell culture. - MSc in Advanced Immunology from Universitat de Barcelona. 

Certifications:
- ISO Management System Audit Techniques and Best Practices 
- Biomedical Visualization from the University of Glasgow
Skills:
 - Poster Designer 
- Blender 
- Procreate 
- Adobe Illustrator 
- Laboratory Techniques
- Teamwork 
- Biochemistry 
- Project Management 
- Scientific Research

currentPositions.description:
🔬Scientific Duties  
•    Perform and support the performance of routine sample analysis biological assays (ECLIA/ELISA) in 
      accordance to established protocols
•     Analyse data and communicate results in an accurate and timely manner.
•     Recognise technical problems as they occur and bring to line manager’s attention.
•     Record experimental protocols and data within the Electronic Laboratory Notebook (ELN) and 
      databases.
•     Contribute to the general organisation of the laboratories and support continuous improvement in 
       laboratory activities.
•     Execute cytotoxicity assays to assess the effects of substances on cell viability and function.
•     Participate in method transfer to Contract Research Organizations (CROs), ensuring seamless 
       integration of research protocols and fostering effective collaboration for extended research 
       capabilities.
•     Proficiently managed cell culture techniques to maintain and study various cell lines.
•     Contribute to the improvement of binding assays, developing new techniques to study molecular 
       interactions more effectively.
•     Lead the development of Antibody-Dependent Cellular Phagocytosis (ADCP) studies by enhancing 
       experimental methods for better understanding of immune responses.

🖌️Graphic Designer Duties
•     Illustrations:  Create clear and informative scientific illustrations to simplify complex concepts.
•     Poster Designer: Design engaging and informative research posters for effective communication of 
       findings.
•      Logo Designer: Design logos for apps created by the teams.
currentPositions.title: Bioanalytical Senior Research Associate

publications.name: “Prognostic value of early endothelial progenitor cells mobilization after an acute atherothrombotic stroke”

publications.description: Electronegative low-density lipoprotein (LDL) (LDL(−)), a modified LDL that is present in blood and exerts atherogenic effects on endothelial cells and monocytes. This study aimed to determine the action of LDL(−) on monocytes differentiated into macrophages. LDL(−) and in vitro-modified LDLs (oxidized, aggregated, and acetylated) were added to macrophages derived from THP1 monocytes over-expressing CD14 (THP1-CD14). Then, cytokine release, cell differentiation, lipid accumulation, and gene expression were measured by ELISA, flow cytometry, thin-layer chromatography, and real-time PCR, respectively. LDL(−) induced more cytokine release in THP1-CD14 macrophages than other modified LDLs. LDL(−) also promoted morphological changes ascribed to differentiated macrophages. The addition of high-density lipoprotein (HDL) and anti-TLR4 counteracted these effects. LDL(−) was highly internalized by macrophages, and it was the major inductor of intracellular lipid accumulation in triglyceride-enriched lipid droplets. In contrast to inflammation, the addition of anti-TLR4 had no effect on lipid accumulation, thus suggesting an uptake pathway alternative to TLR4. In this regard, LDL(−) upregulated the expression of the scavenger receptors CD36 and LOX-1, as well as several genes involved in triglyceride (TG) accumulation. The importance and novelty of the current study are that LDL(−), a physiologically modified LDL, exerted atherogenic effects in macrophages by promoting differentiation, inflammation, and triglyceride-enriched lipid droplets formation in THP1-CD14 macrophages, probably through different receptors.
publications.name: Electronegative LDL Promotes Inflammation and Triglyceride Accumulation in Macrophages
